3046: Gustha's Scepter.author: Enchantment_Removal
3046: Gustha's Scepter.text_parsed:
I really really wish that, for mostly innocent cards like this, that Wizards would engineer them to not have stupid bugs in them. There are several cards that are begging for the clause "..., if (this card) is still on the battlefield, ..."

The first activated ability should read like so:

" T: If Gustha's Scepter is still on the battlefield under your control, exile a card from your hand face down. You may look at that card anytime blah blah."

As the wording is now, if you activate the ability, someone can respond by removing the Scepter, causing it's leave-play trigger to trigger. This trigger would happen before you remove a card. After all of that happens, your activated ability happens, which if I read correctly, forces you to remove a card from your hand anyways. If the intervening if-clause were there, then you have a safety net in activating that ability.

Other cards that need the phrase, "..., if (this card) is still on the battlefield, ..."
Oblivion Ring
Faceless Butcher
Actually all of the Judgement and Torment Nightmares except Wormfang Drake
...I may add to this list later...

3046: Gustha's Scepter.author: tavaritz
3046: Gustha's Scepter.text_parsed:
@Enchantment_Removal: You've understood Magic completly wrong. That effect you describe is acknowledged Magic strategy in many cases.

Not that WoTC isn't known to hose strategies by errating cards or changing rules. Two cases that comes to mind are:

1. Poly and Continous artifacts working while tapped(1). They errated few but not all and ruined many decks.

2. Power Surge made obsolete by eliminating manaburn.

(1) For those who don't know what this was about I repeat it here:

In the begining there were mono-, poly- and continous artifacts. Mono artifacts tapped when used (check Alpha Mana Vault), poly artifacts didn't tap when used (check Alpha Soul Net) and continous artifacts just lied there and affected the game (check Alpha Winter Orb). Now the rule was that you couldn't use tapped poly artifact and tapped continous artifact didn't work (of course you couldn't use tapped mono artifact either because tapping was cost to its use, but more on that later).

Now WoTC removed the definitions mono-, poly- and continous artifacts by strapping the nefangled tap symbol (no, not the existing: check Revised Mana Vault) to mono artifacts in Revised edition and changed the artifact rule to say: non-creature artifacts don't work while tapped. Now the Mana Vault, said the nitpickers, won't ping the controller and they cannot untap it, because it doesn't work when tapped. This of course was ridiculous bull, but the WoTC rules commitee took it into their heart, pondered a while and made the ruling. Instead of returning back to the working mono-, poly- and continous artifacts separation they decided that tapped artifacts work and errated some continous artifacts not to work while tapped (check Howling Mine). Winter orb didn't get that errata and so that strategy is then gone.

Artifact creatures has always worked just like any other creature.

3051: Phyrexian Devourer.author: iUseBreakOpen
3051: Phyrexian Devourer.text_parsed:
The comments here have mentioned Necrotic Ooze, but haven't mentioned the other piece of the combo that makes this so deadly. (It has already been posted on the Masters Edition version of this card, but I'm re-posting it here for more visibility.) The other piece I'm referring to is Triskelion.

1. Buried Alive for Necrotic Ooze, Triskelion, and this.
2. Re-animate Necrotic Ooze
3. Exile a card from your library to get a +1/+1 counter, remove a +1/+1 counter to deal 1 damage to your opponent. Repeat as needed.
3051: Phyrexian Devourer.text_posted:
The comments here have mentioned Necrotic Ooze, but haven't mentioned the other piece of the combo that makes this so deadly. 1. [autocard]Buried Alive[/autocard] for [autocard]Necrotic Ooze[/autocard], [autocard]Triskelion[/autocard], and this.
2. Re-animate Necrotic Ooze
3. Exile a card from your library to get a +1/+1 counter, remove a +1/+1 counter to deal 1 damage to your opponent. Repeat as needed.

3067: Casting of Bones.author: majinara
3067: Casting of Bones.text_parsed:
Well, it's score is low wolfbear2, because it's unreliable.

Example: you want to draw cards now. But maybe neither you nor your opponent have creatures in play. Or maybe there are creatures in play, but you have no way to kill them. Or maybe in response to you playing the aura, someone gets rid of the target, by killing it, or bouncing it. Then your aura is countered. Or maybe once the aura is in play, someone bounces the creature before you can kill it. Or puts it on top of it's owners library or whatever. So, it's not horrible, but it's just too unreliable to be really good.

3068: Casting of Bones.author: blurrymadness
3068: Casting of Bones.text_parsed:
On Card Advantage:
- Neutral- assuming you can kill it without using another card (I.E. it chump blocks or something)
- 1 Disadvantage - If you use a kill spell it's card disadvantage
- Neutral - If instead you use it on your own creature you'll spend 2 and discard 1
- 1 Advantage - Draw out a kill spell successfully on your own creature
- 1 Disadvantage - (the typical issue with countering auras.)

That all said, it does happen to provide useful card filtering (like a decent brainstorm or some such) but it's conditional, sorcery speed, and costs {2} more. IMO it's usable for filtering, but black has better draw, Sign In Blood and it's kin guarantee card advantage without all of the restrictions, phyrexian arena, dark confident, and similar can also help you here.

Similar to burn or bounce decks, black typically needs *advantage* to keep going due to all of the discard/sacrifice mechanics, so IMO, i'd rather nab something that provides that.

But! Similar to what I've said elsewhere on sorcery-speed things, Leyline of Anticipation can turn this into a slightly better Altar's Reap.

3071: Dystopia.author: YawgmothsWish
3071: Dystopia.text_parsed:
Tremendous value for mono-black decks, especially with the timing of the requisite white or green permanent sacrifice, and the scalability of the effect.

If choose to pay 0 life, each opponent sacrifices 1 white or green permanent during their own upkeep. If you choose pay 1 life to keep it to let it mess up an additional opponent's upkeep, you'll get rid of a 2nd permanent; etc...

Moreover, this is basically mono-black's only way of getting rid of troublesome enchantments.

3079: Keeper of Tresserhorn.author: Sumai4444
3079: Keeper of Tresserhorn.text_parsed: Average Rating, 2 stars, and I will debate he is 3 stars easy. First only ONE BLACK in the casting cost. Many decks with new cards nowadays can run prism decks.Sure back in the day this was difficult, but not by any means nowadays in MTG.You can use 5 any color people! And the whole COP:Black, are you fricken kidding me?Life Loss cannot be prevented, it is not damage, it is LIFE LOSS!!!Read your cards and rules please:) In fact this nasty guy was MADE to help counter said PESKY COP DECKS!!! Furthermore, in a well made deck, colorless mana has a way of disappearing. Creatures likeStormscape Familiar, and spells like Helm of Awakeningjust to name a couple. And lets not forget favorites like Sol Ring and Mana Vault to eat through that colorless casting cost. Oh wait this is black, how many Dark Ritual variations are there now?Cabal Ritual, Sacrifice,Bubbling Muck, Burnt Offering, Culling the Weak...the list goes on and ON! Then there is that pesky Bog Witch.Okay mana production isn't an issue, but in addition to ALL that, black has this nasty habit of T1-ing a creature to the graveyard then bringing it into play with so many different reanimation spells...hmmm. Sure there are lower casting cost creatures that can do nastier and better things. But life loss on a habitual basis truly pwns all. Rivaled only in my opinion by Infectous Horror and Pulse Tracker. Fact is with all this in mind this card is 3.5-4 stars easy, in the hands of true deck building genius.

Then there is that pesky [autocard]Bog Witch[/autocard].Okay mana production isn't an issue, but in addition to ALL that, black has this nasty habit of T1-ing a creature to the graveyard then bringing it into play with so many different reanimation spells...hmmm. Sure there are lower casting cost creatures that can do nastier and better things. But life loss on a habitual basis truly pwns all. Rivaled only in my opinion by [autocard]Infectous Horror[/autocard] and [autocard]Pulse Tracker[/autocard]. Fact is with all this in mind this card is 3.5-4 stars easy, in the hands of true deck building genius.

3081: Krovikan Plague.author: ScissorsLizard
3081: Krovikan Plague.text_parsed:
@sonorhc: You can still pay the "tap enchanted creature" ability even if the creature is tapped. It won't do anything to the creature, but you can pay the cost. It's sort of like using Arena to target two creatures that are already tapped. That's why they needed to put the last line in there- to prevent you from paying the cost repeatedly.

What an amazing card this would be if it weren't for that darned Oracle text. Pay {0} to stack the ability a thousand times, instant win. Oh well.

3089: Ritual of the Machine.author: Lord_Ascapelion
3089: Ritual of the Machine.text_parsed:
From the name, you'd expect this card to have something to do with artifacts... guess not, though.

Actually, that expectation aside, I like the flavor of this card. "Ritual of the Machine" is a really awesome card name and the fact that there isn't an immediately obvious flavor connection gets your imagination running. After thinking about it, it seems to be referencing Phyrexia.

As for the power of the card, it's certainly not better than Control Magic. It has targeting restrictions and requires a sacrifice. Not to say that it's bad, or that it may be preferable to Control Magic in a number of situations (no enchantment to disenchant, after all,) but generally, I'd say Control Magic is better.

3091: Soldevi Adnate.author: Kenji18
3091: Soldevi Adnate.text_parsed:
Oh my, is this guy amazing.
Play him with Dross Golem for some crazy mana excel.
Use him with Restless Apparition. Attack with the apparition on turn 4, then when you opponent attacks you, you can sac him, then use the 3 mana to pump the persisted apparition to block as a 4/4.
Use him with any Shade or Consume Spirit. Your opponents will have to block every shade you attack with because of the on board mana excel.
Use him with affinity creatures, such as Frogmite or Myr Enforcer.

Amazing with unearth creatures, too. Consider Viscera Dragger. Cycle for , unearth for , attack, then sac to get 3 damage for no card disadvantage and no mana lost. It gets a little more silly with Corpse Connoisseur. , search up an unearth creature, sac him for mana, play something else. Next turn, unearth him, sac him to net mana and get another unearth in the gy, play something else. Then unearth 1 of the 2 you put in the gy, such as Undead Leotau to deal some decent damage, then sac him to net . He gets more powerful by just using Sedris, the Traitor King, though. Just some things to think about.

Lots of possibilities with Soldevi Adnate.

3092: Stench of Decay.author: HuntingDrake
3092: Stench of Decay.text_parsed:
Amazingly, to this day there is still no simple instant "All creatures get -1/-1 until end of turn."
Nausea's a sorcery, and is still a sorcery under its new name, Shrivel.
Blinding Light, Stench of Decay, and Hideous Laughter are as close as it gets.
It's kind of a pity that Night/Day wasn't printed with more symmetrical effects.

Update 18 months later:
They skipped right past it: Cower in Fear!

3098: Arcane Denial.author: FuriousGeorge
3098: Arcane Denial.text_parsed: There are plenty of decks this card is good in. Does that make it a good card? not necessarily. As far as card advantage goes decks like rule of law and orims chant/ isochron decks take all the advantage out of card advantage making this a very playable card because it either forces discard or thins the deck into the hand, bringing a deck that much closer to depletion. Outside of stuff like that it can work as a quick counterspell cantrip for decks that win before the card advantage can matter. Its a really good niche card, so youre not going to see it in the average deck because there are plenty of cards that fill its role more efficiently in those sorts of decks.

It's not for some silly hand-overload deck.

It's not for an Underworld Dreams deck.

It's for that deck with 30 counterspells which needs to just stop the opponent from doing anything while it combos out. For that use, it is another copy of Counterspell which also replaces itself. Your opponent's hand size doesn't matter it you're just going to counter everything anyway.

It's not a good card, but it has its uses.

3103: Browse.author: jonb86
3103: Browse.text_parsed: Browse was a key card in a combo control deck I ran in Extended back some years ago called "Zur's Worship". I'd use Words of Worship with Zur's Weirding, I'd keep gaining 5 life during my draw step while my opponents never drew a card; I'd use Browse to get cards into my hand (Browse doesn't actually draw cards so it ignores Zur's Weirding's replacement effect). The deck got 2nd place in the tourney. Those were fun times. This card defiantly still has some play value if anything cause it ignores "draw" trigger and replacement effects and lets you pick from 5 cards when the exiled cards are redundant.

3104: Diminishing Returns.author: blurrymadness

I like this card, just don't use it in combo.

It works great if you're not relying on specific pieces but instead relying on controlling the game. Late game use this to fill up your hand and get all your goodies back into your deck. Sure... you'll exile *some* of them, but again.. you shouldn't be relying on just a card or two to power you through if you know you have a 1/6th chance to hit it with this. Still, the likely hood of exiling *all* of your win cons is quite low.

3107: Force of Will.author: Salient
3107: Force of Will.text_parsed:
"Mana Drain is why we distinguish Vintage from Legacy as separate tournament environments. Force of Will is why we still have tournaments at all."

I think back to that quote every three months or so, when a brand new shiny turn-three combo deck swarms the Top 8 lists... until control decks riding on the back of Force of Will re-emerge to bring that to a halt. In the past couple years alone, Force of Will saved Legacy at least seven times:

Painter's Servant + Grindstone. Check. (Forced to run artifact recovery.)
Ad Nauseam + Tendrils of Agony. Check. (Forced to run Silence type spells or lots of Duress effects.)
Vampire Hexmage + Dark Depths. Check. (Forced to run Duress effects.)
Survival of the Fittest + Vengevine. Half-check; they still needed to ban Survival.
NO RUG Natural Order + Progenitus. Check. (Forced to run Verdillion Clique and Red Elemental Blasts.)
Hive Mind + Summoner's Pact. Check. (Forced to run a counter-control suite.)
High Tide + a bunch of janky draw spells. Check. (Forced to run counter-control.)

The combos above emerged or re-emerged as dominant presences in the past two years. They're still powerful and a significant part of the scene, but without blue control leaning on Force of Will to "keep them honest," they'd all be janky unstoppable bombs that don't even bother to include any spells that even pay attention to what the opponent is doing.

One card, keeping the entire. Legacy. tournament. scene. alive. For over a decade, now.

That guy in the picture is making the rage face you would be making if you didn't have the Force of Will in hand to stop your opponent's crazy stupid combo. Instead you can let the Will do the talking for you -- Force their precious draw spell, lean back relaxed as they watch their storm fizzle, and inquire, "U MAD?"

Of course they're mad, dear blue mage. You just saved Legacy again.

3107: Force of Will.author: mdakw576
3107: Force of Will.text_parsed:
The funny thing is that despite how strong this card is, it has actual glaring weaknesses. FoW is actually very bad against "fair" decks, and are usually boarded out there. A maverick deck getting his mother of runes forced goes "okay, well he lost 2 cards to my 1 and the game still continues".

FoW is at its best battling combo decks, and while it also goes with combo decks too, combo decks tend to unload their hand quickly, meaning they have more problems keeping a blue card in hand to pitch to FoW, while control decks more often have extra cards in hand.

Force is basically the "you're about to win and I have one last-ditch-effort thing to do." This can be the fat that lands on the table to flip the game on it's head, this can be combo; this can be the Hymn to Tourach about to ruin your perfectly crafted hand.

It's always exaggerated to mythic power-levels (not the rarity mind you) because it's "free", but it's card disadvantage that's meant to keep the game in check; and it does so by eating something valuable from your hand.

3107: Force of Will.author: Pongdok
3107: Force of Will.text_parsed: As boring as control makes games for players who prefer to see something happen, you still need to respect a good counter spell. This is a great counter spell; right up there with Counterspell. It is sad that a magnificent format devolved to the point that players needed to either run a full set of these or lose before getting to take a turn. Fortunately, that only appears to happen in big tournaments when 'players' want the prizes more than a decent game. Mono blue turn 1 (or turn 0) combo decks are a good place to store your P9 and any number of other antisocial nonsense cards. Nobody without the prerequisite number of Force of Wills will ever play against you. This card makes it so that all of those other great cards can see the light of day, instead of just gathering dust on your shelf (or in your safe, or vault, or whatever). Awesome art. Good flavour. Great effect. 5/5 Never reprint this.

3111: Lat-Nam's Legacy.author: jsttu
3111: Lat-Nam's Legacy.text_parsed: why does this have the new card frame? I understand why the masters version does, but why this one?
3111: Lat-Nam's Legacy.text_posted: why does this have the new card frame? I understand why the masters version does, but why this one?

3111: Lat-Nam's Legacy.author: Daijin26
3111: Lat-Nam's Legacy.text_parsed:
@jsttu: Because this card was reprinted with the new frame for the Coldsnap Theme decks; these cards are collectively known as the Coldsnap Theme Deck Reprints. The Coldsnap Theme decks included some cards from Ice Age and Alliances and kept their original expansion symbols, but reprinted them on the new card frame (Ice Age's Brainstorm for example was reprinted like this.) The cards' rules text were also updated to use the most current wording on the time of reprint.

Also updated on the Coldsnap Theme reprints was the use of the different expansion symbol rarity colors. Remember that the rarity colors on the symbol was first used in the Exodus set; Ice Age and Alliances was long before that. However, no rare cards from Ice Age and Alliances were reprinted for the Coldsnap theme decks, only commons and uncommons.
3111: Lat-Nam's Legacy.text_posted:

3111: Lat-Nam's Legacy.author: ThatStunna
3111: Lat-Nam's Legacy.text_parsed:
Quite underrated. It replaces the worst card in your hand and itself. I'm pretty sure there's some card for 2U that lets you draw two and then discard one; having this for one cheaper is better. You could run some color hosing cards or specific counters and just plan to toss them to this card if they aren't needed.

Remember, it's an instant that you would play near the end of your opponent's turn (usually), so the annoying "next turn's upkeep" isn't as big of a deal as usual.

3117: Soldevi Sage.author: majinara
3117: Soldevi Sage.text_parsed:
Underrated in my opinion.
This guy is a late game card. Costing only two mana allows you to play him, and have enough mana available for counterspells. Saccing lands in that phase doesn't hurt much either, especially for an ability as powerful as drawing two of the three best cards on top of your library. And that's just when you slap him in an average control deck.

Other possibilities are:
- blue black reanimation decks, where you can draw three cards, discard a good creature from among them to reanimate it, and keep the other two
- threshold decks, since each time you tap the guy, your graveyard gets by 3 cards bigger
- crucible of worlds to simply replay the sacced lands
- decks where you temporarily steal other players lands. Like with herald of leshrac
- when you play with lands you don't mind beeing destroyed, like flagstones of trokair or riftstone portal

3119: Storm Crow.author: Salient
3119: Storm Crow.text_parsed:
Storm Crow jokes first emerged with Alliances, because you could pitch Storm Crow to Force of Will. The joke began as a reaction to the over-the-top blue hype of the day -- between Force and Diminishing Returns, many people said that Alliances had given Blue all the best cards. There was some serious-sounding hyperventilative discussion of whether it would ever be sane to play any other color. "Alliances broke blue" is the sort of thing people would say, as well as "Force of Will makes any random blue card better than every other card in the game." Stuff like that.

In response to that, people would jokingly assert that Storm Crow must be the most broken card ever, because it was blue and printed in Alliances. This made all the more sense because of the flavor text (you can read "the worst" as "the worst card ever" literally or as "the most devastating card ever" playfully).

Most players who make Storm Crow jokes nowadays aren't aware of the history of this tradition, but hey, it's great fun to see people get so much amusement out of such a mediocre card. And I like the jokes about the new reprint flavor text better anyhow. Storm Crow returning, we'd best get to burning! :)

"Alliances broke blue" is the sort of thing people would say, as well as "Force of Will makes any random blue card better than every other card in the game." Stuff like that.

And I like the jokes about the new reprint flavor text better anyhow. Storm Crow returning, we'd best get to burning! :)

3121: Storm Elemental.author: Ragamander
3121: Storm Elemental.text_parsed:
This card would be cool if it cost 2UU and if there were no such thing as "reach." Or if it were a 5/5. Or if it let you look at the top card of your library.

Really, if you're going to try to sneak damage past opponents for 6 mana, you might as well use Plasma Elemental, Deepchannel Mentor, Ghastlord of Fugue (5 mana), Saprazzan Breaker (5 mana), Higure, the Still WInd (5 mana), or even Wormfang Crab. Even Graxiplon one-ups Storm Elemental, in my opinion.

I can see Storm Elemental being somewhat useful against decks with dangerous flying creatures, but it is still overpriced, and is thus not even a good sideboard card.

3122: Suffocation.author: Lord_Ascapelion
3122: Suffocation.text_parsed: Not nearly as good as its counterpart, Burnout. Blue usually doesn't win by flooding you with damage, but by controlling the board. Unless you're playing a very aggressive blue deck, this card will not really get you any closer to winning. Burnout can protect red's spells, which it usually needs to win. The only good thing is the card draw added. I suggest that if you want to hose red, include something like Flash Freeze and not this thing.

3123: Thought Lash.author: stygimoloch
3123: Thought Lash.text_parsed: I'd been playing for about two years when I first saw this card in the old (but new at the time) Magic Encyclopaedia, and couldn't believe it. Why would they print a card so bad? Why would you ever play a card that's going to end up removing your library from the game? Was it a joke? It got reputation among players I knew as the single worst card in the game, worse even than Sorrow's Path. Well, just like a gruesome car crash or an example of plastic surgery gone wrong, some things are so horrifically awful they become almost hypnotic. I just had to get a copy of Thought Lash, I became obsessed with owning a copy. Finally I did, I bought one from a trader at a convention who was moderately sympathetic to why I wanted it. I must've read the card fifty times, pored over the artwork, spent a while thinking about it, and realised that the whole pointwas to remove your library from the game, then started thinking with an open mind about why exactly one might want to do that. It was kind of my epiphany moment vis-a-vis looking for hidden depths or tricks concerning each card, and thus the game in general.

3123: Thought Lash.author: majinara
3123: Thought Lash.text_parsed:
The card ain't bad, it's just only useful for certain decks, which is a big difference. I once made a deck on MTGO which consisted of one of each blue card I own + lands, it had a size of about 500 or 600 or so. Then I played this deck in a multiplayer game and played this card. I can assure you, that my opponents then very pretty sure that this card is not bad. :P

More serious: people underestimate the card. It basically says "you gain life equal to the size of your library". ~40 life in a 60 card deck, ~80 life in an EDH deck, ~200 life in a prismatic deck and any amount of life in casual decks where you choose any size you like. And blue cards gaining you that much life are few. It's not a perfect card, but it is very well designed and makes lots of sense in a few decks.

4/5

3128: Bounty of the Hunt.author: themlsna
3128: Bounty of the Hunt.text_parsed: If I put the counters on a Spike Drone or something, and I move the counters to another creature, do the counters still get removed?
3128: Bounty of the Hunt.text_posted: If I put the counters on a [autocard]Spike Drone[/autocard] or something, and I move the counters to another creature, do the counters still get removed?

3128: Bounty of the Hunt.author: nammertime
3128: Bounty of the Hunt.text_parsed:
@themlsna: You'd have to remove the appropriate number of counters from the creatures on which you put them, regardless of how you move them around afterward. That means if you put one counter on a Spike Drone, then move that counter, you'd still have to remove one counter from the Drone when required. The other counter still goes wherever you want it, but you'll likely have lost your Drone.

You could possibly avoid this fate by playing Spike Cannibal after playing this card, but it'd only be a gain if you weren't playing any other Spikes.

3128: Bounty of the Hunt.author: IanB
3128: Bounty of the Hunt.text_parsed:
There are some goofy things you can do to make the counters permanent by moving them around. One example would be putting them on a creature with no other +1/+1 counters, then sucking them over to a Cytoplast Root-Kin. You can do similar stuff with Power Conduit and Simic Guildmage, probably some other stuff I missed.

Some more stuff that gets around the drawback of the disappearing counters one way or another:

Ghave, Guru of Spores can turn the temporary counters into permanent saprolings.

Ion Storm or Molten Hydra can turn them into burn.

You could also use this to draw cards with an under-countered Etched Oracle as long as it wasn't paid for with only colorless mana.

3129: Deadly Insect.author: The_Erudite_Idiot
3129: Deadly Insect.text_parsed:
Like Erhnam Djinn, Deadly Insect is obsolete now, but in his day he was a champio. The strategy was to play this guy in a red-green deck. The burn cleared the way for the Insects. Anything too big to bolt would be a decent trade, but with mana ramp (including Orcish Lumberjack and Tinder Wall, this guy could usually beat the opposition fatties out of the gate.
Sure trample and haste would have made him better, but this guy didn't really suffer their lack.

3137: Gargantuan Gorilla.author: achilleselbow
3137: Gargantuan Gorilla.text_parsed:
It's not great considering that nowadays you get Pelakka Wurm for that mana cost, but this is about as close as green comes to creature destruction, let alone repeatable creature destruction. Run it with Dense Foliage to make sure it doesn't get removed after you sac a forest, and you'll be the only one in the game with removal. The ability to kill just about any creature on tapping will compensate for the card disadvantage of losing your lands, and after you get rid of their blockers, you can just kill them with a couple of attacks. You'll be able to clear their board even quicker if you have a Seeker of Skybreak. I might try this out.

You could also run Stampeding Wildebeests and keep bouncing Harvest Wurm, both of which are efficient creatures.
3137: Gargantuan Gorilla.text_posted:
It's not great considering that nowadays you get [autocard]Pelakka Wurm[/autocard] for that mana cost, but this is about as close as green comes to creature destruction, let alone repeatable creature destruction. Run it with [autocard]Dense Foliage[/autocard] to make sure it doesn't get removed after you sac a forest, and you'll be the only one in the game with removal. The ability to kill just about any creature on tapping will compensate for the card disadvantage of losing your lands, and after you get rid of their blockers, you can just kill them with a couple of attacks. You'll be able to clear their board even quicker if you have a [autocard]Seeker of Skybreak[/autocard]. I might try this out.

You could also run [autocard]Stampeding Wildebeests[/autocard] and keep bouncing [autocard]Harvest Wurm[/autocard], both of which are efficient creatures.

3144: Hail Storm.author: Internet_decks_lame
3144: Hail Storm.text_parsed:
Non-creature green damage is quite rare, and usually doesn't fit the theme for most green mages. And if someone is looking for burn they will usually splash red for the such. Although with this card lies the heavy element of surprise. No one would expect a card like this especially from green. Not to mention this instant against a mass attack could be a game winner against certain decks. Maybe not a main deck card, but against a goblin deck in legacy format your fog turns into certain death for the hording goblins. Not to mention all of the weenie white with red hate will fall to this mass removal as well. It also ruins dredge decks as long as you find something else to control their Flame-Kin Zealot. It is also a nice solution against the Storm deck if they go the route of Empty the Warrens. Can definately find its way into sideboards, main deck don't think so. Just the fact that green has a pyrcloasm should elevate this card to a higher rating. Pyroclasm cards have forever been the nightmare of so many weenie/token decks.

4/5

3146: Nature's Chosen.author: gasimakos1
3146: Nature's Chosen.text_parsed:
There is nothing on the card that states that it can tap your opponents creatures. The card allows you to untap the enchanted creature, which you must control, one time. You can also UNTAP target artifact, creature, or land, but the enchanted creature has to be white in order for you to use the second ability.

All in all, its a very limited card that's only on-par with instill energy if youre playing g/w. Even then, instill energy isnt all that great so that aint saying much. 2/5

3146: Nature's Chosen.author: blurrymadness
3146: Nature's Chosen.text_parsed:
While this *can* be better than instill energy; imagine this vs. that in a ramp deck. Instill Energy works on both mana-dorks (extra untap for more mana) and on fat (haste.) Being able to get that out of a single card is pretty nice.

This is better for GW where you want something to get some kind of vigilance, or you have flash available (as you'll untap up to two lands) and that sort of thing. I don't think it's fair to say one is better than the other since they meet such different needs.

3148: Splintering Wind.author: sonorhC
3148: Splintering Wind.text_parsed:
Actually, giving this away could work. The damage when the tokens leave play is an ability of the enchantment, not of the tokens. So you make a bunch of tokens (killing some things in the process, of course), attack with them for as long as you can afford them, then Donate the enchantment (Bazaar Trader unfortunately doesn't work with enchantments). Now, when your Splinters die, they'll make your opponent and his creatures take the damage, not you.

This is the same way it worked with the wording printed on the card, so I'm not sure why anyone's complaining about the Oracle wording.
3148: Splintering Wind.text_posted:

Now, when your Splinters die, they'll make your opponent and his creatures take the damage, not you.

If that is what happens with multiple tokens, this just got hilariously worse in my eyes. Still an interesting card, but, really? They all kill one other, in turn hurting you even more?

That's definitely a splintering effect, alright.

3149: Taste of Paradise.author: Lateralis0ne
3149: Taste of Paradise.text_parsed:
Ultratog:

Replicate allows you to choose new targets for the spell every time you pay the replication cost, and also repliacte copies the spell each time the cost is paid. Taste of Paradise doesn't allow these actions. It is indeed much more closely related to multikicker, as that allows for multiple instances of mana paid to attain more of the given action.

3151: Tornado.author: NARFNra
3151: Tornado.text_parsed:
It's green creature destruction that doesn't just apply to fliers. And it can hit multiples... Now, if this didn't have such a large cost combination, it'd be quite playable. But in order to destroy just one creature, you need to pay {6}{G}{G}. To destroy two, you pay that plus {2}{G}{G} and 3 life... So really it's only usable if you've got a lot of mana to spare and nothing better to do. I'd use Desert Twister if I really needed Green destruction, to tell the truth.

2/5

3153: Undergrowth.author: Talcos
3153: Undergrowth.text_parsed:
I like this card. It's a very unusual design. Clearly seated in green, but with a red twist on it. But I would think that, if they had to redesign this card for a modern set, they would change "red creatures" to "creatures you control." You already had to spend red mana to activate the ability, it would make sense that you probably had red creatures or red/green creatures and so on in your deck.

But this card should not have kicker. It was not originally printed with kicker, and there are cards that interact with kicker. So giving it kicker would change the functionality of the spell.. then again, Wizards has changed other things, like creature types, in the past, and those changes altered the functionality of cards, so it's not impossible for them to do.

Boost the toughness a bit, and lock down your opponent's Baneslayer Angel, or Zur, the Enchanter or Nicol Bolas, etc. etc. All those dragons like Rith, the Awakener lose all their additional abilities. 3161: Balduvian Horde.author: Equinox523
3161: Balduvian Horde.text_parsed:
This card is a bit like a star basketball player in college, who got drafted amid lots of buzz, going on to a disappointing pro career. It's well-documented why RANDOM discard on yourself, in a color poor in card drawing (especially at the time) is bad, so I'll talk about the other aspects of this card.

I for one actually enjoy the Erg Raiders-esque flavor of it. A bunch of barbarians you can call to your side cheaply, get riled up, but then have to appease to keep them fighting for you. Mechanically, more recent card, Cragganwick Cremator, seems to have drawn its inspiration from this famous red creature of old, instead providing a perk for the discard, instead of using it purely as a drawback. It turned a dreaded, potentially game-breaking drawback to a hope that you will discard Draco and possibly kill your opponent.

3167: Chaos Harlequin.author: majinara
3167: Chaos Harlequin.text_parsed:
Nice card, makes you think, and you can build nice decks around him.

Once you removed the lands from your library (there are enough ways to do that), he is quite strong. Pay a mere three mana, and he is 8/4 until end of turn. That should normally kill any player quite quickly. In case of doubt, add Mirror of Fate to your deck. And add fling.

Sure, he ain't a Tier 1 powerhouse, but I think most people don't even try think on how to make him work. Exiling cards is by default no problem. Once you stripped the lands from your library, it's basically impossible to mill yourself. You'd, before that happens, have easily killed any opponents.

2/5 for beeing not too strong
4/5 for beeing creative
I give him a 3/5.

3167: Chaos Harlequin.author: Monty_Sigurdson
3167: Chaos Harlequin.text_parsed:
Decent with stuff like Lantern of Insight, Orcish Spy or Goblin Spy (as others have pointed out already). Note that you can also use him to remove unwanted land cards from the top of your library (but you should do that after combat, for obvious reasons :) ).

A good card to have, but only if you know what the top card of your library will be. Otherwise I wouldn't recommend playing him, since he'll probably be 0/4 most of the time then or you'll waste tons of mana for very little benefit.

Can be tons of fun in the right deck though. 3/5.

3167: Chaos Harlequin.author: Technetium
3167: Chaos Harlequin.text_parsed:
Bad card. Most decks have around 1/3 land (actually around 23-24 is best usually), so on average, you get nothing from 3 consecutive uses of the card and you've lost 3 cards from your deck. Permanent loss of cards from your library is a substantial cost in itself that should return a reliable bonus. The card would be much more balanced like this:

R, exile the top card of your library from the game: If the card is a land, -4/-0 until end of turn. If it is a non-land, +4/+0 until end of turn.

Alternately, you could make him a little more crazy like this:
Exile the top card of your library from the game: If it is a land, -1/-0 until end of turn. If it is a non-land, +1/+0 until end of turn.

the latter option allowing use limited only by the number of cards you're willing to exile. It should take approximately 30-40 cards removed from your library to reach him being a 20/4, which is pretty huge but at the same time super risky should your opponent respond to the last use with Terror or Terminate.

W is the best EDH color- or almost (tie with B?)

3182: Soldier of Fortune.author: TheWrathofShane
3182: Soldier of Fortune.text_parsed:
Shuffling helps you draw land.

Think of it this way. Say your land is 10 cards deep, that sucks but possible. At the start of the game your shuffle is cast and you have a 91% chance to draw your 2nd land. But your not going too, its 10 cards deep. The variable is known and set, just not known to you.

But say you shuffled every turn. What are the odds of you failing a "roll" multiple times in a row? A lot slimmer then only failing 1 roll and waiting 10 turns to find out.

3182: Soldier of Fortune.author: LordRandomness
3182: Soldier of Fortune.text_parsed: Good against Sensei's Divining Top, but also very good with it: just shuffle away your top three if they're not what you need and try again. Invaluable against top of library tutors of all kinds, as well as for turning your Griptides and the like into removal (and commander tucking to boot). Also works very well with or against anything that reveals anyone's top card (Fun and often game-saving versus Melek, for instance) and with any other scry effects. All in all, an interesting and unique combo piece that compares very well to the much more limited Madblind Mountain.

3189: Veteran's Voice.author: HuntingDrake
3189: Veteran's Voice.text_parsed:
Modern text-splicing technology yields:

Veteran's Voice

Enchantment - Aura
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature has ": Another target creature gets +2/+1 until end of turn."

Though this archaic version does have the advantage of ignoring summoning sickness...
Also this way it's always a red ability, as opposed to being whatever color the creature is.

Ugh, I just learned that this had the cleaner, text-splicing template until the Scars of Mirrodin update.
If we can declare that ": Pay THIS to do THAT" should always be interpreted as "Pay THIS: Do THAT", why can't we declare that the intent of these old cards was to splice the ability onto the enchanted permanent?
3189: Veteran's Voice.text_posted:
Modern text-splicing technology yields:

[b]Veteran's Voice[/b]
[R]
Enchantment - Aura
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature has "[T]: [autocard multiverseid="2991"]Another[/autocard] target creature gets +2/+1 until end of turn."

Though this archaic version does have the advantage of ignoring summoning sickness...
Also this way it's always a red ability, as opposed to being whatever color the creature is.

Ugh, I just learned that this had the cleaner, text-splicing template until the Scars of Mirrodin update. 
If we can declare that "[0][b]:[/b] Pay THIS [b]to[/b] do THAT" should always be interpreted as "Pay THIS[b]:[/b] Do THAT", why can't we declare that the intent of these old cards was to splice the ability onto the enchanted permanent?

3189: Veteran's Voice.author: ThatStunna
3189: Veteran's Voice.text_parsed:
The card would be better and more thematic if the card also had "When Veteran's Voice is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, you may return Veteran's Voice to play enchanting a target creature you control that does not have summoning sickness."

That way, the card could be given to any veteran (as in a creature that had been in play). Alternatively, there could be text allowing you to cast the card from your graveyard with flash when a creature you control attacks or blocks.

3192: Errand of Duty.author: jfre81
3192: Errand of Duty.text_parsed:
Since banding was more useful than anything on defense, an instant-speed banding weenie is better than most people realize. Let's say suddenly you have a big trampler, like a Berserked/Blood Lusted Ball Lightning and I've only got one little creature to block with. Hit this, block as a band with your two weenies and because of banding the defending player gets to distribute the damage. Banding was an effective trample killer.
Knight Exemplar basically turns the token into a 2/2 endless blocker. You can assign all that trample damage to him too per the banding rules.
3192: Errand of Duty.text_posted:
Since banding was more useful than anything on defense, an instant-speed banding weenie is better than most people realize. Hit this, block as a band with your two weenies and because of banding the defending player gets to distribute the damage. Banding was an effective trample killer.
[autocard]Knight Exemplar[/autocard] basically turns the token into a 2/2 endless blocker. You can assign all that trample damage to him too per the banding rules.

3200: Kjeldoran Home Guard.author: longwinded
3200: Kjeldoran Home Guard.text_parsed:
There are a couple of different approaches they took to tokens. Some they updated because the name they already had imply a type: Minor Demons are demons, Wasps are insects, and Sand Warriros are warriors. Some tokens -- such as thrull, saproling, and goblin -- have synergistic card sets built around them, so of course those don't change.

The most they could do with citizens, deserters and so on is make them humans. Take Citizen tokens: if they had wanted the tokens to be townsfolk (the type used for all civilians back in FE), they would have called them that. For that matter, they could have actually let them be soldiers or knights from the beginning. The fact that they deliberately chose a type that doesn't match any type found on a creature card suggests that the tokens were meant to be one-off, expendable guys with no tribal synergy. The same for the serfs made by Sengir Autocrat. Changing the types might thus be seen as changing the original design intent of the card, rather than a simple update.

3202: Kjeldoran Pride.author: DacenOctavio
3202: Kjeldoran Pride.text_parsed:
Dragon Scales is wonderful for reanimator decks, and as such, doesn't actually require mana to cast. The Dragon Auras from Scourge, particularly Dragon Breath, tend to show up in Legacy Cephalid Breakfast. Since Breakfast decks routinely mill their entire library turn 2, flipping over 3 Narcomoeba to sacrifice to the flashback cost of Dread Return on a huge guy, who then gains free haste from Breath, people generally prefer the Dragon cycle.

However, this aura stems from a time early on in MTG's development. This is one of the first auras to feature an ability that mitigates the disadvantage of casting aura spells; you were able to move this to another of your creatures (or, if you're a clever player, you could move it to one of their creatures temporarily and then play another one of your own guys and move it onto him to avoid losing the aura completely). As such, this card represents an important milestone on the road of good aura design; relatives of this aura include Flickerform and Angelic Destiny, both designed to work around the inherent card disadvantage of playing with the card type.

3203: Martyrdom.author: EvilKhelso
3203: Martyrdom.text_parsed:
You have to think bigger. Check this out.

Use any Redirecting Kor creature, like Warrior en-Kor.

Naturally, you can use Stuffy Doll, but Martyrdom and Stuffy Doll alone does not annihilate someone.

Finally, you need Retromancer.

Step 1) Play Martyrdom on Stuffy Doll or Warrior en-Kor.
Step 2) Tell your Warrior en-Kor to redirect the next one damage from himself to Retromancer.
Step 3) Retromancer retaliates and assigns 3 damage to you.
Step 4) You use Martyrdom and send it to the Martyr'd creature. If it's the en-Kor, tell it to throw it to Stuffy Doll. If it's Stuffy Doll, watch your opponent take 3 damage.
Step 5) ---Step 2
...
Yes, I made Retromancer broken and yes, when I do this, I cast Cloudshift on my Stuffy Doll and kill the next person which is why I Martyr the en-Kor.

3203: Martyrdom.author: Salient
3203: Martyrdom.text_parsed:
It's weird to see that nobody so far has mentioned the only competitive deck that actually uses this card, Cephalid Breakfast.

You use this granted ability targeting Cephalid Illusionist thirty times, dump your entire library into your graveyard while putting 3-4 Narbomoeba into play, and then you Dread Return for the win. (Used to be Sutured Ghoul + Dragon's Breath FTW, but nowadays people use Laboratory Maniac + Deep Analysis.)

There are more competitive mill-your-own-library decks, but this is definitely the most entertaining. It's just so awesome.

3214: Scars of the Veteran.author: MacBizzle
3214: Scars of the Veteran.text_parsed: For some reason, the 7 damage prevention to one target in a game of magic just seems ridiculous. I feel like it would be a weaker card if it said "Prevent all damage that would be dealt to creature or player this turn, put a +0/+1 counter on the creature (if applicable) for each damage prevented this way." I mean, obviously, that would be way better, but singular damage increments as high as 7 just leaves more of an impact than "all" damage. The thought that you'd need 7 damage prevented to turn the tide of a war would be ridiculous (your opponent would be aiming to kill your creatures exactly, or near exact damage), but for exiling a white card, this is definitely worth it. That being said, this card looks pretty impressive with a big figure like 7 and it's pretty effective with the pitch cost.

3217: Sworn Defender.author: Krysto
3217: Sworn Defender.text_parsed:
The de***ion on this is waaaaay too wordy, and the mana-pump is a slight turn off, but unlike sentinel, this girl is good for attacking AND blocking, whereas sentinel needs a power buff first.

Drop a holy strength on this and for one mana it'll block anything AND kill it unless it's indestructible.

Sure, 4 mana is a bit mid-to-late for this, but that's just in time to block out the late game killers.

So for 1 mana it's just short of killing it's prey and just above being killed by it. For an extra 1 mana you can update those stats to counteract any buffing your opponent can do, but don't get in a pump-war with a shade.

Viscous with trample - 1 mana guarantees it'll be ready to spill over some damage with a small boost, but be VERY careful with attacking because multi-blocking will mutilate this.

I would not mind a reprint of this.

3222: Lim-Dûl's Paladin.author: DoctorKenneth
3222: Lim-Dûl's Paladin.text_parsed:
As a lover of somewhat convoluted mechanics and cards that have "middle-of-the-road" quality, this card has a certain appeal. I kind of like the general idea. Used right, with the strategies achilleselbow mentioned, he's fairly okay.

However, the big issue I have with this guy is the flavour. Why, exactly, does he get this large boost in power when he fights a creature? Some kind of battle frenzy? Why can he not be as badass all the time? Does he have to stop and catch his breath afterwards, shrinking down to a 0/3? It's a little hard to piece together why he's effectively a 4/3, 0/3, or 6/6 depending on how he happens to feel at the time.

3222: Lim-Dûl's Paladin.author: achilleselbow
3222: Lim-Dûl's Paladin.text_parsed:
5 for the art alone. One of Christopher Rush's best, which is to say one of the best artworks in MTG overall.

And yes, people are overlooking its combo potential with Madness, Hellbent, or reanimation. Plus he fits perfectly in a knight deck with Haakon, Stromgald Scourge. He gets Haakon into the graveyard where he needs to be, and after that you just keep discarding other knights which you can cast just as easily from your graveyard.

@DoctorKenneth: I'm not sure either, but it's a recurring theme with Lim-Dul related cards. See Keeper of Tresserhorn, for example (basically a crappier version of this guy). It may be that they get physically strong when fighting normal corporeal creatures, but affect a planeswalker through more arcane life-draining means. Also the 0/3 may be because he is sustained by necromancy and is really just a lifeless corpse. I know he LOOKS human, and they gave him the human creature type, but come on, it's LIM DUL's paladin.

3222: Lim-Dûl's Paladin.author: scumbling1
3222: Lim-Dûl's Paladin.text_parsed:
This is how to design a bad card exemplified.

You have a base value for it's stats: 0/3.
Then you have his stats if it gets blocked by anything: 6/6.
Then you have yet another value to remember - the life loss inflicted if it isn't blocked: 4.
Furthermore, throw in the fact that he has an upkeep to keep track of (Not to mention, the upkeep has the counter-inuitive aspect of allowing you to draw a card if it's not paid)! That's a bit too much going on for a single card.

It's a bunch of disparate numbers and abilities that are NOT in anyway helped out by envisioning them from a flavor standpoint (who knows what is meant by his life loss trigger?). It's not even a remotely useful card, either, so I can't understand in the slightest what the intention was for this paladin.

Oh yeah - it's a Red and Black paladin! What the hell?

3222: Lim-Dûl's Paladin.author: yyukichigai
3222: Lim-Dûl's Paladin.text_parsed:
Love this card. Opponents generally aren't sure how to react to him (short of instant-kill or something) and he's pretty robust. Even though the loss of 4 life isn't that much, somehow the fact that it's unpreventable life loss makes it hurt that much more. What essentially amounts to a 4/3 that can become a 6/6 in combat for 4 mana with a manageable upkeep cost isn't bad at all.

This guy used to be the center of a very effective Ice Age-block deck back in the day, alongside Ashen Ghoul, Nether Shadow, and Death Spark. Death Spark could be discarded again and again and again to the Paladin provided you could kill off at least one of the Shadows or Ghouls every turn, which wasn't that hard given how little toughness they have. Generally attacking with one every turn would wind up with the thing dead. Keep in mind this was in the days of Howl from Beyond, so your opponent generally wasn't going to let a black attacker through if you had a bunch of mana untapped.

3224: Lord of Tresserhorn.author: BobbySinclair
3224: Lord of Tresserhorn.text_parsed:
I tried, I mean I REALLY tried, to use this guy as my EDH general. He's a 10/4 zombie, with a kick-ass name and artwork. He's cheap and has regen for only B. But, no matter what I did, he just was not effective enough. It's fine having a hypothetical general, but in the majority of my real EDH games (which are multiplayer) he did nothing. 1v1, I feel he may very well have an edge, but in most EDH games, LoT is not going to be useful. And I say EDH games, because in most 60 card decks, I am fairly certain he won't be considered.

Firstly, he dictates your deck thoroughly. Sure you can slap Topor Orb in (which is in fairly boring), but that's one card in 100. You have to find it. Then he doesn't have trample of evasion, so add in cards for that. You're effectively running a Voltron deck, and it leaves little room to do any other crazy stuff with what is an awesome tribal: zombies. So why not just run another Voltron deck? And if so, there are plenty of other generals out there who suit this style of play much better. LoT sits in the uneasy realm of not really a standard Voltron general, and not really an awesome zombie-tribal general.

Secondly, I can certainly deal with life loss, and perhaps even want my opponents to draw cards in a group-hug kind of way. But the MUST sacrifice 2 creatures is what puts this card waay out of reasonable playability for me. EDH is a slow format. I know hardly anyone that has more than a couple of one-drops in their deck. Don't let that 4 mana casting cost fool you - you'll not be seeing Mr Tresserhorn for a while. Until you've set up a token system, or put out a few expendable creatures. Even then, with the number of instant-speed removals in EDH, you'll need to make sure you have at least 3 creatures out, just in case. And even then, bounce mechanics are prevalent in EDH. Mystifying maze, bouncy angels, blue cards, etc etc… LoT gets bounced far too often and will either have to sac himself, or sac nearly your entire board. And if your Topor orb is still out when he gets bounced, your opponents aren't playing right.

I'm sure if you're lucky, or determined, you'll get him to work most of the time, but for tribal or voltron, there are simply better options. For me, he's going in my collection and taking pride of place there. There's no denying he's a cool card. Just not one I'd use as my general.

3225: Misfortune.author: DarthParallax
3225: Misfortune.text_parsed:
Questions:

1. What, if anything, does "DALE" mean?
2. Why do you think an opponent choosing automatically makes it bad? Painful Quandary is good.
3. It can be a one-sided Wrath of God...well, almost none of the time.
4. How many cards in Green-Black that use the word 'whenever' are good with this card's life-changing effects?

BUT if you play into what the card wants you to do, you can build a tokens army. Your opponent definitely won't enjoy you getting a Glorious Anthem (theoretically the second-worst of the 4 abilities) if you use liberal amounts of Trample, Deathtouch, First strike, and Double Strike (the main combat abilities of these colors. Skip Flying, Lifelink and Vigilance as it would overextend the deck too much unless you try to twist it around Dragons, in which case mana becomes an issue).

The gain 4 life is the worst clause, but in my questions I note that it's probably comboable. True, it would an excercise in practicing your Johnny Thinking, but this card has got to be at least 3 stars in 'any old Jund creatures deck', but it could be built around to be a blowout 4.32 stars card if you try very hard. :)

It's absolutely paramount to play creatures with good keywords with this card. Vampire Nighthawk gets you flying and lifelink, so you could maybe find an odd Red Knight with Vigilance?

3232: Heart of Yavimaya.author: Lord_of_Tresserhorn
3232: Heart of Yavimaya.text_parsed:
@Plantboy81: The two lands you mention demand the sacrifice of an untapped land, whereas the three other just need a land of a specific type.

It's debatable which method is better. Heart and the two others force you to play something after putting them into play (you float the mana from the Forest before playing Heart) so that you don't just lose the land. Balduvian/Soldevi on the other hand rob you of colored mana production which can hurt. Also, using the extra abilities of Balduvian/Soldevi "costs" more mana since tapping them deprives you of two extra man, not just one.

3233: Kjeldoran Outpost.author: Equinox523
3233: Kjeldoran Outpost.text_parsed:
Some information about the dreaded Counterpost decks of old for all you youngsters:

https://www.wizards.com/Magic/Magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtgcom/feature/86

What can I say about this land? A huge part of counterspell decks is the ability to do something with that mana you left open should your opponent pass the turn. This allowed you to get a creature to attack and defend with, one that could attack immediately if you used this ability on their turn. As a land, this is uncounterable, and as a player of counterspells, you could thwart their attempts on killing your Outpost. A lot of these decks also played Wrath of God for when things got out of hand, but you would be able to pump out a soldier on an empty board, provided you had the mana for it.

In modern times, land destruction is not as prevalent as it once was, and the Soldier tribe has tons of support, making this card once again quite powerful.

3234: Lake of the Dead.author: blurrymadness
3234: Lake of the Dead.text_parsed:
Interestingly it puts out enough mana to fuel Liliana of the Dark Realms who in turn powers this out.

In GWB you can use Flagstones and crop rotation to get this out T1 (grab a godless shrine as a plains and grab this with crops), then you can have BBBBB on T2 if you have another swamp.

Also, If you drop this T3, you can tap *both* of your swamps and sac one, netting you 6 mana T3 without any shenanigans; most people here seem to drop it T2 and then get stuck with 5 mana.

3236: Sheltered Valley.author: blurrymadness
3236: Sheltered Valley.text_parsed:
I, for the life of me, cannot figure out why people don't like this.
I keep looking for a real drawback to running 1 in any deck, but aside from the colorless mana I don't see it.

Many decks run curves of 3 mana or less with spells not being color intensive; in any deck that occasionally gets mana-screwed, wastelanded, etc, this guy nets you as much as 5-10 life over the course of a game.

Won't happen that often as a 1-2 of in your deck; but it's really not that bad for being "legendary" and colorless. 2-stars does not do this justice. As a 1-of in pox? You'll be gaining health all game to replace the life you're slowly sapping.

4/5

3238: Thawing Glaciers.author: Cyberium
3238: Thawing Glaciers.text_parsed: When Glacier was available, it wasn't used for fixing color as the fetch lands today are, but to thin your deck indefinitely in mid to late game when you have spare mana so you don't have to draw them again. For that purpose, Glacier is very powerful.
3238: Thawing Glaciers.text_posted: When Glacier was available, it wasn't used for fixing color as the fetch lands today are, but to thin your deck indefinitely in mid to late game when you have spare mana so you don't have to draw them again. For that purpose, Glacier is very powerful.

3238: Thawing Glaciers.author: StuartHamilton
3238: Thawing Glaciers.text_parsed: it's not just for use as a deck thinner. With this thing in play, it means that you never miss a land drop for the rest of the game. Think about it. For the rest of your control mirror, you're always going to have lands coming in, meaning you will inevitably outclass your opponent's mana production, and have tremendous leverage as a result. It's a lot more powerful than it seems at first glance.

3238: Thawing Glaciers.author: blurrymadness
3238: Thawing Glaciers.text_parsed:
Goes well with Ponder and Brainstorm, as well as any others who card about fetchlands (Vampire Nocturnus, Delver of Secrets, etc..), consider using with something like Lantern of Insight to help you decide what to keep or not keep.

Also consider many of blues untappers to not only get repeat use out of this land, but to help you actually get ramping out of it. Let it be known that Blue, Black, or White, who typically don't get ramp, love ramp. Blue can use instant speed stuff to ramp 2-3 lands at the end of it's turn before you know it; meaning that spell they held over for you turned into not only card advantage, but mana and tempo advantage. Giving that to blue is a surefire way to lose. This makes you *want* them to counter your spells, which is exactly what they actually want too.

Consider Rewind, Cloud of Fae, Snap, and other untappers, along side things like hidden strings (every cast becomes card advantage), Jolt/Infuse/Twitch (basically instant speed draw + ramp), Clock of Omens + liquimetal, or many other untapping combos
